entry.title: Skills Architecture Playbook: 10 Design Decisions with Talent Intelligence Hub that Define Success !
entry.content:
The shift towards a skills-based workforce is picking up speed, and this transformation lives or dies on one thing: your skills architecture, the foundation that defines:

  • how skills are structured,
  • how they are governed,
  • how they flow through your HRtech landscape, and
  • how employees, managers, and admins actually experience them.

What‚Äôs happening -
Most organizations jump straight into ‚Äúskills projects‚Äù without stopping to define the design decisions that truly matter! I have seen SAP SuccessFactors customers engaging with different HRTech or Skills vendors separately, rather than as a coherent group. The result? Duplicate skills across systems, messy job profiles, confused employees, frustrated managers, and governance models held together with duct tape.

Think of this blog as your Skills Architecture Playbook: the 10 decisions every company must get right to build a clean, future-proof foundation with Talent Intelligence Hub. These decisions will shape everything from AI models and inference reliability to employee growth journeys and manager adoption.

If you‚Äôre implementing TIH, planning a Skills Transformation, or just trying to bring order to the skills chaos, this guide is for you.

Let‚Äôs get into the decisions that define your success.

Leading Practice Skills Architecture with Talent Intelligence Hub

Here‚Äôs a leading practice approach for designing a Skills Architecture with TIH at its core. Open Skills Ecosystem (OSE) partners help augment and complement customers' internal data, creating a high-quality skills foundation that brings together market skills data, job and work insights, and people attributes.

Once standardized in Talent Intelligence Hub and enriched with employee and organizational master data from SuccessFactors, this unified skills intelligence can be delivered through Career and Talent Development (CTD) as the experience layer for every persona -employees, managers, HR, recruiters, and leaders.

I had shared this diagram in my session at SuccessConnect and have further explained it in my podcast. Give it a listen -  Art of the Possible - Episode 1 - Skills-based Transformation - Talent Alchemy Podcast series

This is how you bring a skills-based transformation concept to life.

1. Choose Your System of Record: Where Does Job & Skills Truth Live?

Everything starts with a single question: Where does the truth sit? 

For job architecture and skills governance, SAP SuccessFactors Talent Intelligence Hub should be your system of record and governance layer.

Here‚Äôs how it breaks down:

TIH + JPB = Your Master Foundation

  • Job Families
  • Job Roles
  • Job Profiles
  • Skills Library
  • Skills tagged to roles and profiles
  1. JPB holds your job architecture. 
  2. Open Skills Ecosystem partners enrich your skills library.
  3. TIH governs and standardizes everything.

Get this foundation right, and the rest of your skills strategy becomes infinitely easier.

2. Standardize Skills in the Attributes Library with AI Skills Standardization

Once you know where the truth lives, the next step is: What does that truth look like? The Attributes Library in TIH is your governance layer for all skills master data.

It helps you:

  • Maintain a clean, unified skills library.
  • Standardizes the Skills data into one common language. 
  • Manage lifecycle states (active, deprecated, standardized)
  • Standardize proficiency scales

Your Open Skills Ecosystem partner sends business- and industry-relevant skill data into TIH, where you standardize it.

This avoids:

  • Duplicate skills
  • Confusing naming conventions
  • Skill inflation
  • Random ‚ÄúHR-created‚Äù one-off skills

This is your quality control engine.

Check out my Talent Alchemy Bits and Bytes segment, where I talked about Skills Standardization. 

3. Decide How Skills Will Be Validated

If there‚Äôs one thing employees love, it‚Äôs adding skills. If there‚Äôs one thing managers love‚Ä¶ It‚Äôs being skeptical of those skills. Validation matters!

You need to decide: 

Who validates the skills?

  • Employee?
  • Manager?
  • Both?
  • Or does it depend on the skill type?

What‚Äôs the sequence?

  • Employee declares ‚Üí Manager approves
  • Manager nominates ‚Üí Employee confirms
  • System infers ‚Üí Employee validates ‚Üí Manager approves

Consistency is key.

Which system is the system of record for validation?

TIH/Growth Portfolio or your OSE partner?

Either works‚Äîjust don‚Äôt let both do it independently. That‚Äôs how data chaos is born.

4. Define Your Skills Signals Strategy

Skills come from everywhere. Projects, learning, bots, assessments‚Ä¶ even legacy tools that are somehow still alive. Your rule of survival:  SAP SuccessFactors Growth Portfolio should be the master system of record for all employee skill interactions.

That means:

  • Employees view and update skills here
  • Managers make decisions here
  • HR governs here
  • Partners feed into here

Other systems can contribute, but they can‚Äôt own the truth

5. Choose What Skills You will Infer and from Where?

Skill inferencing is magical‚Ä¶ unless it pulls the wrong signals. You need to define:

What external sources can infer skills?

  • Project systems
  • Legacy HR/LMS tools
  • External learning platforms
  • Gig/mobility platforms
  • Assessment vendors

How will you judge quality?

Set thresholds such as:

  • Evidence required
  • Confidence level
  • Relevance to job or industry
  • Duplication rules

Which SF processes continuously infer skills?

  • Learning completions
  • Internal gigs
  • Performance achievements
  • Career development activities

A thoughtful inferencing strategy prevents ‚Äúnoise skills‚Äù and keeps your profiles trustworthy.

6. Decide Where Employee Skills Data Should Flow

Once an employee‚Äôs skills are updated and validated, where does that data go?

Typical downstream consumers include:

  • Recruiting
  • Learning
  • Opportunity Marketplace
  • Workforce planning
  • Career & succession tools
  • Assessment vendors
Important: "If you have multiple skills-enabled vendors (LMS, recruiting, assessment tools), Growth Portfolio remains the master. Application partners consume standardized data; they don‚Äôt manage it. This keeps your ecosystem clean and consistent."

7. Define How the Skills Taxonomy Will Be Propagated

Your skills taxonomy flows outward from TIH into the rest of the ecosystem.

TIH is your:

  • Skills system of record
  • Job architecture governance tool
  • Standardization engine
  • Master metadata source

If you use multiple Open Skills Ecosystem (OSE) partners:

Pick ONE to be your skills architecture provider. Why?

Because multiple skills dictionaries = chaos.
One dictionary + TIH governance = sanity.

8. Design the Employee Experience (Growth Portfolio and..)

Employees are the heart of your skills ecosystem. Decide:

How much ownership do they have?

  • Full self-declaration
  • Only inferred skills
  • Only validated skills
  • Only view or able to manage skills
  • A blended model

What should they see?

  • Validated skills
  • Inferred skills
  • Critical or core skills
  • Skill gaps

How guided should their experience be?

  • Single entry inside SuccessFactors
  • Some interactions inside partner tools
  • Or a completely unified Growth Portfolio experience

The goal?
Keep it simple, intuitive, and aligned to growth, not admin work.

9. Design the Manager Experience (Teams View and...)

Managers are where skills turn into results, development, mobility, and readiness. You need to define:

How much oversight managers have: Do they validate? Approve? Only for critical skills?

How deeply do skills feed talent decisions

Should they use skills to:

  • Recommend learning
  • Suggest gigs
  • Nominate for roles
  • Support succession plans
  • Plan team capabilities

What feedback loops they own

After:

  • Projects
  • Assignments
  • Reskilling initiatives

Manager feedback becomes key evidence for skill proficiency.

10. Design the Admin Experience (Governance, Analytics, and ...)

Admins run the heartbeat of your skills ecosystem. Define:

Who owns the skills library?

  • HR COE?
  • Talent?
  • Learning?
  • A cross-functional governance team?

How partners integrate

External vendors must feed into Growth Portfolio without duplicating or reinventing your skills.

What KPIs HR will track

Some examples:

  • % validated critical skills
  • Internal fill rate
  • Mobility rate
  • Skills coverage vs. demand
  • Time-to-proficiency
  • Learning-to-skills conversion

Conclusion: Your Skills Architecture Is Your Future

Building a skills-based organization is not about collecting skills, it‚Äôs about creating a system of truth, a system of intelligence, and most importantly, a system of experience that employees and managers trust.

  • Talent Intelligence Hub gives you the governance layer.
  • Growth Portfolio with CTD (Career & Talent Development solution) provides the experience layer.
  • Your open ecosystem partners give you the enrichment layer.

But your design decisions tie it all together.

Get these decisions right, and skills become the engine behind: talent mobility, workforce agility, learning personalization, internal career growth, and more. Get them wrong, and you‚Äôll spend months reconciling data, chasing inconsistencies, and wondering why adoption is low.

With Talent Intelligence Hub at the center and these 10 decisions guiding your journey, you can build not only an architecture, but a future-ready, human-centered skills ecosystem that actually works.

entry.title: Implications of Functional User license for Contingent workers when using onboarding
entry.content:
In this article we will discuss how a contingent worker is hired as an employee via SuccessFactors Onboarding and how this may affect the functional user license in SuccessFactors.

There are number of ways a user in SuccessFactors Employee Central can be a functional user:

  • They do not have access to SuccessFactors platform i.e. no login permissions in RBP.
  • They are seasonal worker with a length of service lest than 1 year.
  • Their details are mastered in an external HRIS.
  • They are contingent worker.

The full and functional user license only applies to SuccessFactors Employee Central.

A contingent worker will always be a functional user whether they have access to SuccessFactors platform or not.

In the scenario where you have a contingent worker who is ‚Äòconverting‚Äô to an employee, this requires a termination and a hire record.  If you initiate onboarding for the contingent worker, they will complete their onboarding record for their new ‚Äòemployee‚Äô record by switching the employment profile switcher.  Clearly for them to do this they will need access to SuccessFactors.  If they do not have access to SuccessFactors and access is given this WILL NOT switch them to a ‚Äòfull user license‚Äô as they are a contingent worker, and all contingent workers are classified as functional users.

entry.title: SuccessFactors Org Design: When to Go Standard, Custom, or Keep It Simple
entry.content:
Not every day does a SuccessFactors consultant get to play detective with organizational structures. Usually, businesses handle the heavy lifting of aligning their data to SuccessFactors (SF) org units. But recently, I got a chance to consult on this very topic‚Äîand wow, it made me think hard about one question:

When do we create a child object in the org unit vs. a custom object vs. just a field in Job Info?

Org Structures: More Than Just Fancy Boxes

For most large organizations, the classic three-level hierarchy‚ÄîBusiness Unit > Division > Department‚Äîis like wearing a one-size-fits-all T-shirt. It works for some, but for global companies with multiple countries and quirky local structures, it‚Äôs a tight squeeze. Each country lead might have their own flavour of hierarchy. But we don‚Äôt want to go wild and create a spaghetti org chart with endless layers. Complexity is not our friend here.

So, before we start harmonizing data and designing the ‚Äúto-be‚Äù org structure, we need to ask:

What‚Äôs the purpose of the org structure in SuccessFactors?

Where do we use SF Org Structure?

  1. Permissions
    • Org units act as filters. Example: Give Sales folks access to certain features while keeping HR out of the party.
  2. Reporting
    • It shows how your company looks on paper (or screen).
    • Filters help too. Example: ‚ÄúHow many HR employees left the Organization last year?‚Äù
  3. Legal & Compliance
    • Some countries require managers to be from the same country. Org structure helps enforce this rule with matching the position hierarchies to Org Structure and by managing matrix relationships in position hierarchy.
  4. Integration Touchpoints
    • Org units flow into S/4HANA and Employee Central Payroll (ECP) if integration is in scope.
    • They can also sync with other downstream systems.

 

Harmonize the Data

Before we dream of a perfect org chart, we need to group data logically across countries. Can we streamline it? Once we know what we have, we can decide how many layers we need. Let‚Äôs say we need five levels. Now comes the million-dollar question:

Do we create child divisions and departments, a custom org unit, or just store info in Job Info fields?

Option 1: Child Units

Pros:

  • Standard configuration‚Äîno extra setup.
  • Easy to maintain and works with standard templates.

Cons:

  • Visualization shows five levels, but employee assignment supports only three levels.
  • Child units appear twice in the org chart (yes, there‚Äôs a workaround, but it‚Äôs extra effort).
  • Reporting still works, but permissions need creative filtering.

Case Study: Retail beverages company

They opted for a simple 3 level structure to manage Org hierarchy and managed to create custom fields to drive Talent Grouping.

Option 2: Custom Org Unit

Pros:

  • Can extend the structure to four levels.
  • Employees can have four-level assignments.

Cons:

  • Not standard‚Äîrequires configuration effort.
  • Does not appear as a standard permission filter.

Case Study: Logistics and Supply chain company with multiple subsidiaries

  • They first considered adding child departments but realized employees could only be assigned to three levels creating difficulty in identifying the multiple subsidiary units.
  • They opted for a custom org unit, enabling four-level assignments for better reporting.
    Result: Balanced complexity with functionality.

Option 3: Custom Field in Job Info

Ask yourself: Do we really need extra layers if they don‚Äôt serve multiple purposes? For example:

  • If it‚Äôs just for payroll grouping, why not reuse PayScale Group?
  • If it‚Äôs for benefits or location grouping, add a custom field like ‚ÄúBenefit Group‚Äù or ‚ÄúLocation Area.‚Äù

This approach is simple, flexible, and avoids unnecessary complexity.

Case Study: Multinational Hair care company

A multinational hair care company had employees acquired out of M&A. Instead altering their Org structure, they created a custom field in Job info to flag them for time related groupings (such as different annual leave quota for them).

  • Result: Simple, flexible, and avoided unnecessary hierarchy.

Final Thoughts

Before adding layers like an onion, ask: Does this serve a real business purpose? If yes, go for it. If not, keep it simple. Sometimes, a custom field beats a fancy org chart.

What do you think? Have you faced similar challenges? Drop your thoughts‚ÄîI would love to hear your take!

entry.title: SuccessFactors 2H 2025: Seamless Talent Data Transfer from Inactive to Active Employment
entry.content:
What‚Äôs New?

SAP SuccessFactors introduces a powerful enhancement via the new feature Transfer Individual Talent Data from Inactive to Active Employment:

"Transfer Individual Talent Data from Inactive to Active Employment"- This enhancement introduces a person-centric Manage Individual Talent Data Transfer capability, enabling administrators to seamlessly migrate an employee‚Äôs complete talent history in a single action from inactive to active employment. 

Key Highlights

The new functionality inaugurates an advanced functionality within SAP SuccessFactors Performance & Goals, facilitating the seamless migration of an individual‚Äôs complete historical talent data from an inactive employment record to their current active employment in a single, streamlined process. This ensures uninterrupted continuity of performance insights across employment transitions, thereby supporting holistic talent management and organizational agility.

Business Use Cases

When an employee permanently relocates to a host country, a new user ID is assigned to them. During this transition, the employee requires access to their talent data originally associated with their home country user ID. In such instances, administrators or HR personnel can facilitate the seamless transfer of the employee‚Äôs talent data from their inactive home country user ID to the newly active host country user ID, ensuring uninterrupted access to their complete talent history.

How to Configure

  1. You have enabled Employee Central to manage multiple employments.
  2. You have enabled at least one of these modules: Goal Management, Performance Management, 360 Reviews, Continuous Performance Management, Calibration, and Career Development.
  3. You have enabled the data transfer tool through Admin Center > Company System and Logo Settings > Enable Individual Talent Data Transfer from Inactive to Active Employment.
  4. You're recommended to configure employment differentiators, which helps you identify and select the correct source and target employments for data transfer.
  5. The subject person for data transfer should have at least one inactive employment and one active employment.
  6. To ensure the person's new employment and their stakeholders have the permission to access the transferred data, make sure module-specific permissions are correctly granted with right target population. For details, refer to the Guide topic in the Related Information section.

Role-Based Permission Pre-requisites

entry.title: 01 SAP SuccessFactors HCM Implementation - Phase 0 Objectives
entry.content:
This blog will focus on SAP SuccessFactors HCM Implementation - Phase 0 Objectives. 

This will be a multi-part series covering each topic in detail in the SAP SuccessFactors HCM implementation. The content is based on my experience leading multiple large-scale SAP SuccessFactors HCM Implementation projects over the past 10+ years.

Why are you doing Phase 0? 

Phase 0 in SAP SuccessFactorsHCM is the critical pre-implementation groundwork, a strategic readiness phase before the formal project implementation kickoff, focusing on business alignment, scope definition, data assessment, and implementation strategy (Transformation or As-is) to ensure project success, reduce risk, and build the business case. It's about defining what you're doing and why, aligning stakeholders, assessing current systems, and planning the Integration, data migration, and change management needed for a smooth transition to SuccessFactors HCM.

Phase 0 Objectives:

The list below covers the broader topics we handle in phase 0. It may vary by customer, but the objective is to ensure a clear strategy, ownership, and solution appropriate in place. 

Phase 0 Objectives Description and Responsibility Matrix:

Commonly asked questions on Phase 0 SAP SuccessFactors HCM:

Question 1: Is Phase 0 mandatory?

Answer: Phase 0 is not mandatory, but for complex transformation projects involving multiple countries, it is strongly recommended.

Question 2: Is Phase 0 Part of the implementation? 

Answer: Yes and NO. Some customers prefer to do so outside of implementation to scope the project correctly (Budget, Timelines, Deployment approach). Some customers choose to do it as part of the implementation. In both cases, the outcome is to achieve the objectives listed above. 

Question 3: Who leads Phase 0? 

Customer leads Phase 0, and the Implementation Partner (SI) brings SMEs. Some objectives are owned entirely by the customer, some are SI, and some are shared. 

Question 4: What is the format of  Phase 0 Deliverables? 

  1. Deliver Process Maps (Signavio, Lucidchart, Miro, etc.) for business process design.
  2. PPT - for Strategy documents
  3. Word document for detailed solution documents

Question 5: Does Phase 0 involve configuration work? 

Typically, no, but it depends on the phase duration. Sometimes, we can do an Iteration 0 configuration, which always helps. 

Question 6: What is the role of the customer in Phase 0?

The Customer Team (Business and IT) owns Phase 0 and ensures its objectives are achieved.

Question 7: What is the role of the SI in Phase 0?

Assist the customer in defining the deployment strategy, and provide expert-level advisory on business process design and solution design for the future state. Align customer goals and bring the right people with experience in similar projects.

entry.title: Considerations when implementing IAS for SuccessFactors Onboarding
entry.content:
In H2 2026 the username and password authentication process for onboarding will be deprecated and they will need to use IAS to log in.  In this article we will discuss various options to consider when implementing IAS for onboarding.  We will assume that IAS is already enabled for Employee Central.

Implementing IAS is quite simple for an onboarding perspective, a switch is enabled in provisioning and emails need to be adjusted.  All the logic in IAS should be built by an IAS consultant.

Emails

When IAS is enabled for onboarding the ‚Äòusername/password‚Äô is sent from IAS rather than from SuccessFactors.  I prefer to still send the ‚ÄòExternal Welcome email‚Äô from SuccessFactors Onboarding.  The welcome email explains that they will get a second email with the login credentials.  I prefer to send two emails as we can customize this email to a greater extent than the IAS email.  In the welcome email you will need to remove the password reset and username, and this will need to be removed for the rehire email as well.  The login link in the other emails will work with IAS.

To get two emails to be sent at the same time will require the real time synch in IAS.

The first email comes from SuccessFactors Onboarding.  This is the external email welcome template. 

The second email comes at the same time from IAS and will allow them to set their password to log in.

To log on they click on the link, and they set their password.

Once they have reset their password they should be redirect to the login page; to do this you will need to set up the redirect in IAS.

Once they have submitted their username and password you can choose to add a new layer of authentication.  Once way is to send a code to their email address.  You can also send this by SMS but this will require a third party provider.

Once they submit the code they will be able to log in.

Once they log in, they can proceed with onboarding as normal.

On their hire date the individual will not get a new IAS account but will be moved to an employee group and they will be able to log in with same IAS account that they used in onboarding.

Rehires

When an employee is terminated from Employee Central then their details are typically deleted from IAS, they can be made inactivated, but it is advised that they are deleted.  ips.delete.existedbefore.entities=true

When onboarding starts the onboardee receives an email as above.  When the rehire, check has been completed it follows the same process as without IAS, they get an new IAS email to go in that is linked to their inactive Employee Central Account.  As the old IAS account was deleted this is new IAS account but liked to the inactive user record.  Once they log in their can proceed with onboarding as normal.

When deploying IAS, it is imperative that the rehire process is fully tested.

Implementing IAS whilst live with Onboarding.

Some onboardees  will be using the old username and password method.  As you approach the deployment, we suggest the following.

  • About 2-3 weeks before go live update the welcome email so users know you are changing the authentication process, and they will get a new email to log in. 
  • Add this to a custom homepage tile, this is just there to prevent any concerns over phishing.
  • On go live day pause all initiation of onboarding
  • Update onboarding IAS email with text applicable to all onboardee who are currently in the process, explaining what they need to do.
  • Synch onboarding with IAS, once this is completed update onboarding IAS email with standard text
  • Restart onboarding initiation

entry.title: 02 SAP SuccessFactors HCM Implementation - Clean Core Guidelines
entry.content:
The purpose of this blog is to share Clean Core guidelines for SAP SuccessFactors HCM implementation, based on my experience. This is not official SAP documentation or recommendation.

Clean Core is a key topic in SAP S/4HANA Transformation projects and must be adopted as part of the S/4HANA Journey. SAP has delivered tools, frameworks, and Strategy documents to support it, but I haven't seen much content for SAP SuccessFactors HCM projects. I hope this blog addresses this to some extent.

Why is a clean core essential in SAP SuccessFactors HCM?

 Clean Core is a set of guiding principles that support continuous business transformation by designing an agile, innovative, and efficient SAP SuccessFactors HCM system, reducing technical debt and manual effort, and adopting a framework for building a maintainable system that leverages standard capabilities wherever possible.

If you are using SAP ERP HCM as Core HR, the system has evolved over the years and is usually customized to support your business processes, Integrations, and reporting. There is a valid reason for customization, but it introduced long-term challenges, technical debt, and high maintenance costs, which are well known, and every customer raises concerns about them.

SAP SuccessFactors HCM Clean Core Guiding Principles: 

  1. Business Processes: Standardize processes (fit-to-standard) to increase efficiency and adapt to market shifts.
  2. Data: Maintain high-quality, consistent data and implement robust governance to improve reporting, Integration, and analytics.
  3. Integration: Use standard APIs (OData, Web Services, ISC), Packaged Integrations, Event Driven Architecture (EDA), and direct API-based integrations to avoid complex custom integrations and Data gaps.
  4. Operations and Upgrades: Manage the lifecycle, ensure efficient monitoring, and adopt the new features of the SAP SuccessFactors HCM system.
  5. Extensibility: Built customer-specific, unique requirements using Extension Center Objects and SAP BTP CAP extensibility using the OData APIs to decouple customizations from the core for upgrade stability and build UI experience using Fiori and implement workflow /automation capabilities using SAP Build.

Business Process Clean Core governance framework:

This is a high-level framework that you could enhance based on your project structure and governance model.

Recommendations for Implementing Clean Core Guiding Principles:

 

  1. SAP SuccessFactors HCM Product Capabilities: Understanding the product capabilities is key to implementing or adopting fit-to-standard clean core guidelines. If the implementation resource lacks SME-level experience, the solution will likely be suboptimal and will usually require significant customization. 2
  2. Guiding principles and standards for each work stream: Create guiding principles and leading practices for each work stream (Functional, Data, Integration, and Extensibility), and ensure the project implementation team, including the customer and SI resources, must follow them as part of implementation to produce outstanding results. 
  3. Skills resources from SI: Having skilled resources from SI (Solution Architect, Functional Leads, and Technical Architect) who are familiar with the clean core implementation is key. Ensuring they own the quality of the work is key and should be part of the statement of work. 
  4. Preferred success service: Preferred success customers -leverage SAP's preferred success services like solution launch checks and success checks to review the SF configuration, Design, Integration strategy, and Integration code during the implementation. 
  5. Review Implementation Design Principles (IDPs): Based on my experience, IDPs are key assets for clean core guidelines. They provide structured guidance for addressing challenging customer requirements and frequently asked questions during the design and implementation phases of a project.

https://pages.community.sap.com/topics/successfactors/implementation-design-principles#sap-successfactors-recruiting-management-and-employee-central-integration 

      6. SuccessFactors Architecture Leading Practice (ALP): ALP is another key asset for clear core guidelines, and it provides a set of recommended configuration decisions and guidance on topics associated with a SuccessFactors implementation, and a recommendation to drive positive outcomes aligned with the intended system design, leveraging proven success from previous deployments, and avoiding pitfalls.

 https://pages.community.sap.com/topics/successfactors/architecture-leading-practices

 7. Integrations: Integration is a common area where extensive customization is done, which adds technical debt and high maintenance costs. Make sure that the resources who built integrations have.

 Prior experience in building integrations for SAP SuccessFactors HCM.

  • Understanding of SAP SuccessFactors APIs leading practices and Integration tools.
  • Strong integration design skills .
  • Understanding of packaged integrations and capabilities.
  • Integration Center and SAP Integration Suite Capabilities, and when to use these tools for custom integrations. 

 8. Leverage standard capabilities to capture quality data: Implementing proper validation business rules and framework to capture data is key . 

9) Data retention and Purge Data: Setting up the proper data retention rules and purging unnecessary data based on your data retention requirements will help you maintain key data. 

10) Monitoring Tools:  Leverage standard capabilities offered by SAP SuccessFactors HCM Suite and SAP Solutions like Cloud ALM to monitor the jobs and schedules, which reduces system maintenance costs. 

11)Handling Product gaps: Some requirements will challenge the product capabilities, and they will be identified as gaps. Now, how you handle the product gaps is very key, based on my experience below,

  • Check if the functionality can be achieved using Extension Center Objects ( MDF). 
  • If MDF is not a solution, then check the Product roadmap to see if anything is planned in the upcoming releases. 
  • If Options 1 and 2 are not viable, then check if the partner has built any BTP Extension solutions in the App store. 
  • If a partner solution is not available, you can leverage the SAP BTP Extensibility Framework to extend SAP SuccessFactors and build the required functionality.

Commonly Asked Questions: 

 1)Creating custom fields and extension Center Objects is deviating from the clean core?

 No. But it is essential to check whether the functionality can be achieved using standard fields before using custom fields and the extension Center (MDF) object.

 2)How can I check if my SI is implementing and following clear core guidelines? 

Having the right skill resources for the project implementation is key. It is strongly recommended that key SI resources be validated before onboarding.

 3) What are the assets SAP has delivered for SI and Customers?

 I have used the following assets, and they have always helped.

  •  Implementation Design Principles covering all topics.
  • Architecture Leading Practices.
  • Process Maps.
  • Leading practices document.

  4)What are the areas that cause technical debt in SAP SuccessFactors HCM? 

Technical debt refers to the implied cost of future rework, Manual work, and maintenance resulting from choosing quick, short-term implementation or configuration solutions over more robust, long-term best practices. 

  • Integrations with External systems ‚Äì Building custom integrations with Poor Integration Design and coding standards
  • Manual workarounds and manual data maintenance processes
  • Customizations over Standard Functionality, Creating custom fields and MDF objects without governance.
  • Not ready to optimize business processes and build a solution that requires so much effort to maintain.
  • Not automating data imports.

5) Is optimizing business processes a must for a clean core?

 Yes. Optimizing some of the business processes is not possible due to various factors, which is reality, but as a customer having a mindset to optimize is very key, and checking the solution design options from the SI team and walking through with business and HR is always recommended.
